segments.text: You were saying that you were talking about the strategic hamlets.
Did you move people into these villages?
No, I never did.
The only time I tried to move some people was at a camp back in my first tour and I was told that we just could not do it.
It was a camp, and I've forgotten the name of it now, but at one time it had the third largest or longest and best airfield in Vietnam.
And the problem was that there were no people there, that most of the people had fled Q2 Viet Cong activity.
As a matter of fact, it was one of the largest camps in Vietnam, but there were very, very few people there.
And it had, prior to 1964, been very heavily populated.
And they had just all fled.
And I wanted to move people back out there, but there was no existing road system
The road system had been destroyed by the VidCon, and primary resupply was by air.
And I had envisioned moving people back into that area, those who wanted to come, give them support for a period of time where they could grow their rice and chickens and hogs and what have you.
and to repopulate the area where they can become more or less self-sustaining, as well as having a surplus to assist in feeding the local troops.
But I faced an insurmountable task in persuading anyone that it would work.
The local government, province chief,
to repopulate in that area.
He felt that once we had gotten the civilian populace out of there, that everyone who remained was VC or VC synthesizer.
Therefore, it was obvious anyone there was not friendly, and that was his problem.
I was sent down from Okinawa with two other officers to assist the U.S. 25th Division in establishing their civil affairs and asylum program when they came into the country.
We got there shortly before they did.
One brigade was in second port.
I can't recall the name of the area where they were.
I traveled out with the first division, first U.S. division.
And unfortunately, as I arrived with the 1st Division, they were going out on an operation.
I believe it was called Buck's Camp.
But their civil affairs officer had gone to Saigon to become educated in the ways and the responsibilities of civil affairs, psyops, refugee control, and this sort of thing.
And he was not there, so I didn't
didn't get a chance to talk to him, find out what he was doing with his division's programs and what kind of programs they had.
My short visit with them, I think, was about two weeks, and I became rather hands-on involved with refugee control, evacuation, feeding, safeguarding, and so forth during that particular operation.

And as a matter of fact, we evacuated sort of 1,000 Vietnamese civilians from the Iron Triangle as it became known, the areas where the 1st Division was operating, in order to clear out and deny the Vietcong
a area of operations for the civilian populace to hide in the area called the Iron Triangle.
This was just after the first major battles in the Iron Triangle?
This was the beginning of the major activities within the Iron Triangle, yes.
At Chi Chi, what was your job?
Did you deal with the tunnel rats?
deal with the tunnel wrecks?
No, not really.
I knew the engineers, some of them I knew a few of, and knew slightly some of the tunnel wrecks in that area.
As a matter of fact, in our area where we moved into just north of Coochee, the third gate
I believe it was the 3rd Brigade of the 25th Division moved in there in, as I recall, late January or early February, I'm not sure of the dates, of 1966.
We found an area there that appeared to be old peanut fields that were not being worked at that particular time.
And that's where they decided to put the 25th Division.
The 1st Division had just prior to that been operating in that area.
But there were a couple of villages close by.
I'd say within a half mile.
And the village of Coochee itself was about three quarters of a mile or a mile south of that area.
And it was not known until later, I'm talking about after the war, how extensive that tunnel system really was.
We did have tunnels within the area, and as a matter of fact,
They blew up one which was only about 50 feet from the absolute inner water where the Tactical Operations Center for the 3rd Brigade was.
And this was, it left a fairly good sized hole in the ground.
And of course this was later filled in because we hadn't used the space for whatever.
And you want some war stories?
What kind of tactics did they use to fight?
You never fought in the tunnels.
No, I did not go into any of the tunnels.
I'm a pretty good-sized boy.
I just wouldn't fit into them.
Besides that, I have a high regard for my skin, and it wasn't my job.
I wasn't going into the tunnels.
What kind of tactics did they use to fight in the tunnels, if any at all?
Primarily, the tunnel rats went in armed with concussion grenades and .45 missiles.
And they would go into them and go as far into them as they could go, commensurate with a reasonable amount of safety.
And usually only two at a time, as I recall, would go into a tunnel.
One to lead the way and the other to back him up and pull him out if he got hurt.
Because the tunnels were very, very small.
As I was told, I was never in one, that for a medium or small size American, the most that they could do would be hands and knees.
and it was crowded on the sides.
Now, I'm sure that there were, and I heard some of them talk about larger rooms in the tunnels that they found.
These larger rooms, however, were not what you call American-sized larger rooms or classroom-sized or anything of that nature, what we would consider
They were all very crowded and very small scale.
Even the larger rooms probably were not more than 5 or 6 feet in height at the very most and maybe 8 by 10, large 8 by 10 feet square.
The ones that I was told about.
I'm sure that from what I have heard since the war was over that they were, in other places, that they were much, much larger.
But they had to be much deeper also than the ones that we were familiar with.
Most of the ones there were six to ten people of the service at the most.
After they would crawl in and check them out, they would attempt to destroy the tunnel itself by the use of explosives.
And they'd set a large charge of explosives down with sandbags and so forth, and then crawl out detonating it by wire, electrical charges.
Were you harassed more by guerrillas here?
We did have some, and I think this is probably one of the tunnels that we may have later found.
We did have on occasion sniper fire landing within the inner wire near the tactical operations center.
I don't believe that
There might have been a couple, three wounded.

The troops out on the perimeter, the battalions that were on the perimeter, they did have a considerable amount of harassment at night, small arms fire primarily, and on one occasion, a either grenade attack or
The mortar attack, I'm not sure which it was.
I was not there at the time.
But I do know that they did have some small explosions within the areas.
This is perimeter troops, battalions that did receive some harassing fire.
And this, of course, was almost every night somewhere along the perimeter.
You mentioned other stories about the tunnels.
Oh, yes, I had a bright idea that we could probably drown them out, and we had the equipment with us, or at least the 25th Division did.
They had a jacuzzi-type water pump, and I'm talking about the pumps that would throw a
four or six inch stream of water and we had the aluminum piping similar to the manner in which they used the same type of pipe for irrigation in West Texas years ago.
And I had what I thought was a bright idea that we could pipe the water from the river
up to one of the tunnel entrances and drowned them out.
But I was told by the engineer officer that I spoke to that it just wouldn't work.
And I had other things to do and just didn't carry through with it.
I think probably looking back in retrospect that none of us at that time knew the extent of
the tunnel system.
And had I known, had we known at the time how extensive it was and the fact that they were allegedly interconnected, that this would have been a pretty good idea.
But unfortunately, it was one of those good ideas that, not knowing the importance of it,
I ignored it, that they thought they were doing a pretty good job with the tunnel rats and blowing most of them up and denying their use to the Vietcong.
And I just let it slide.
Didn't do anything about it.
What was the esprit of the Green Beret in Vietnam after the first major buildup?
My experience with the Green Berets,
After the first major buildup, I was never again with the Special Forces, other than just visiting on occasion.
What was their esprit de corps?
As far as I could tell, it was not as high as it had been.
They were continuing to operate somewhat as they had.
They were going more for, as I recall, long-range patrols.
They continued to operate their training camps and continued to work as they always had, but were placing more emphasis on long-range patrols.
And as I recall, they were operating cross-border patrols into Laos and Cambodia.
to some extent, I think probably more into Laos, trying to locate and cut the Ho Chi Minh Trail.
And of course, as we all know, the Ho Chi Minh Trail was a number of trails.
And as I have learned
Later, it was actually a quarter-way highway in many places, protected by bamboo and tree camouflage.
It was a tunnel, above-ground tunnel, so to speak, through vegetation in many places for miles and miles.
And I have no idea how many man-hours
spent building the tunnel, but I do know that I heard stories from time to time, but I was never privy to actually seeing a part of the Ho Chi Minh Trail as such that I knew what I was looking at.
What was the view, what was your view, what was the general view of Westmoreland in his search and destroy strategy?
I really had no understanding at that time of what a search-and-destroy strategy was.
The few conversations I had with General Westmoreland and the few times that I briefed him concerning the activities of the 25th Division, civil affairs and psyops,
It appeared that he was a firm believer in the idea of win their hearts and minds.
To me, he did not appear as bloodthirsty as he's sometimes been made out to be.
It appeared to me that the search and destroyer was
search and find the VidCon and destroy them.
And since those years it's appeared in publication and writings of different types that it was a search if you don't find anything destroy it type of thing.
At least this is the impression I gained from the
printed and electronic media at this time.
That is what was either going on or that's what the reporters think was going on.
I personally did not see any destruction of civilian property other than that which was absolutely necessary.
And most of the
unfriendly villages were left alone.
If they were not actively participating in the war, they were left to do what they wanted to do.
Was there friction between the Special Forces and regular forces of the Army?
And if so, what was it about?
I'm going to give you one word answer, no.
I didn't see any friction between them.
Now, there may have been,
But I was not privy to any friction.
The Special Forces that I knew, and I did not know any in 1966, the Special Forces camps were not within the areas that I operated in 1966 because this was not the ideal terrain.
for the special forces to operate.
Was there any friction about whose tactics were right?
Should we have been using conventional or unconventional tactics against the enemy?
Or what kind of tactics were?
I really don't understand that question.

You must understand, I think I understand what you're asking, but if you're talking about military tactics per se, the special forces and regular forces or conventional forces tactics are just not compatible.
Conventional forces primarily were designed and still are designed to take and hold

special forces tactics were designed and are still in the unconventional mode, fighting an unconventional enemy to seek out and destroy the base camps, seek out and destroy their lines of communications, and to harass them on their lines of communications.
Of course the conventional forces had to adopt some of that in their long range patrols as well as with their short range patrols.
And in many cases they put the fairly large forces, large numbers of troops on their lines of communications.
I'm sure that the regular forces were primarily responsible for most of the search and destroy type operations.
We didn't like the term as such because it portrayed a different attitude than that which we really had.
We were not there to destroy Vietnam.
We were there to safeguard the civilian populace and to protect them.
That was our feelings at the time.
That was my feeling, and I don't believe that I was too far different from the average soldier I might have been.
What about the relationships between the Green Berets and the Vietnamese civil authorities during the build-up?
And are you referring to the 1966 era?
Well, I did not wear the Green Beret in 1966.
I did not want to call attention to myself as a Green Beret.
But the civil authorities that I knew were very cooperative with all the military.
Now that does not mean to say that they were not looking out for number one.
As a matter of fact, that was the biggest

headache that you saw or at least that I saw during my entire Vietnam experience that the Vietnamese civil government at district level it was a military government and at province it was a quasi military government

But even so, be they military or civilian, they had a tendency, and I hate to say that they all were, but most of them were very self-oriented, meaning that if it was good for their career, if it was good for the pocketbook, then by all means it was good for them.
It was good for everybody.
But I would say that by and large, the Vietnamese civil government was very corrupt.
And there were many exceptions to that.
But unfortunately, I ran into a number that proved the world wrong.
They were cooperative.
For instance, if you had 1,000 sacks of cement to build a school and it took 1,000 sacks, you better order 1,500 or 2,000 sacks.
That's about the same for any other commodity, building materials and so forth.
It just seems that the corruption was pervasive.
When you left at the end of 66, did you think there would be a Tet Offensive?
No.
I knew the war was going to be coming to a close before tomorrow, and I perceived incorrectly as it later turned out.
I believe the tail of Fancy was the tail of 1968, was it not?
Yeah, I see.
And we're talking about over a year.

At the time I left there in 1966, December I believe it was, it was not a friendly war, but at the same time it was, it seemed to be depressing that there was a lot less activity other than defensive on the part of
the VidCon.
I believe that the government forces, including U.S. forces, were pressing right along and with a great deal of success.
But naturally, there were incidents where the VidCon did attack.
and in most cases against sometimes strategic hamlets, sometimes engraved forces against special forces camps.
And on infrequent occasions, primarily in the highlands, the Viet Cong were able to build up and to operate against
U.S. military forces to some extent, but not with any great success.
As I stated, it was primarily defensive in nature.
Why did you believe the war was coming to an end?
I believed our own propaganda.
And quite frankly, at that time, the NBA had not
come down in strength.
There were isolated instances of NDA units, but the war was not being fought by NDA.
It was being fought primarily by VidCon.
The infrastructure of VidCon was on the run.
Were you, again, you were debriefed when you left.
Did anybody listen to what you had to say?
Sure.
My debriefings were incorporated into area studies that were ongoing within the Special Forces, Special Action Force Asia.
We're all about debriefings.
When you left Vietnam in 1966, you eventually ended up at Fort Polk to train troops before you went back again.
When you were training troops, did you use the experiences in Vietnam to help you train troops to go to Vietnam?
I used my experience primarily as a self-motivator.
to motivate me and my NCOs, officers, to make them understand the importance of training the troops properly.
What did you think of the training process?
I was involved in basic training rather than
advanced individual training.
In 1967 in Fort Polk, we had the ideal training environment, at least as far as we could have it in an active post within the United States, being that it was hot in the summertime.
And the humidity was high, which is the way it is in Vietnam.
And we began to acclimate our troops, at least the troops that I had to train.
They became rather well acclimated to the heat and the humidity during the summertime.
without having actual jungle to train in, I think we did rather well.
As a matter of fact, just as an aside, Vietnam is not all jungle, and Vietnam is not all rice paddy.
During a period of time, and I don't recall, I guess it was during the 1964, I landed at a dirt
airstrip in C-123.
And that, when I got off the airplane, I looked around and I felt like I was a little bit of deja vu.
It was like Highland in New Mexico, the high-level plains of New Mexico, burnt grass.

cactus, adobe, what appeared to be adobe buildings around, and the terrain, short distance around the airfield and as far as I could see at that time, looked like the high mountains or high plains of New Mexico.
You returned to Vietnam in May 1968 to May 1969 as military advisor to the 51st Arvin Regiment, I Corps near Da Nang.
What did you think was the result of the Tet?
What do you think was the outcome of the Tet?
You're talking about the Tet Offensive?
The Tet Offensive of 1968.
In my opinion, and I am
I'm still a firm believer that this was the division between phase one of the Vietnamese experience and the second phase of the Vietnamese experience.
I'm talking about the  prior to this time, we had, and during the so-called Tet Offensive

We have been fighting the Vietcong that is primarily most of the combat operations have been carried out against Vietcong that is indigenous South Vietnamese, sometimes led by North Vietnamese, sometimes augmented by North Vietnamese.
The Tet Offensive was a disaster for the

I believe that we, during the Tet Offensive and the months immediately after, I'm saying for three to six months after the Tet Offensive began, that we effectively won the war that we had been fighting.
And I don't know to this day
I can't put my finger on any particular thing that eventually lost the war in Vietnam or eventually caused us to leave and the South Vietnamese to lose the war.
But... How was the morale in the ARVN and American forces?
Very high.
Very high.
As a matter of fact,
Most of the people that I knew subscribed to that feeling.
Most of the people that I knew had the feeling, especially those who had been there during the Tet Offensive.
I was not.
But most of the people that I knew thought it was a winding down process, that it was strictly a mopping up and clean it up,
and we'll be ready to go home in a few months.
Because it appeared that there was nothing else there to fight, or very little.
It was just about enough exercise that needed to be carried on.
You say that you believe that we'd won the war we had been fighting.
What do you think that war was, in your opinion?
It was a guerrilla civil war up to that point.
with outside assistance from the North, Vietnamese and, of course, Chinese and Russians.
But at this particular point, the Viet Cong as an entity effectively ceased to exist.
It was no longer a civil war after that point, in my opinion.
In 68, 69, were the Arvin forces any better fighters after five years of heavy training?
Well, the turnover was fairly significant all the way through, considering that the South Vietnamese were taking fairly heavy casualties.
And I still believe that the 51st Arvin
was a rather professional fighting force.
They were reasonably well trained, even by U.S. standards, and they were well led.
In many cases, the officers were junior officers.
For instance, a captain would be commanding a battalion in many cases.
In the U.S. Army, a lieutenant colonel commands a battalion.
But if you look at the experience of the officers we're talking about, we're talking about six, eight, ten, fifteen years' experience in the military.
And much of that time they had actually been on the ground fighting the Viet Cong.
And I think they were, in many cases, very well trained.
The noncommissioned officer corps, of course, many of those young men had been in the Army at times similar to the officers.
Of course, there was always the new troops' replacements coming in, being drafted and brought into the military.
And the primary problem that they were having
was that the pool of manpower was beginning to become rather shallow, that the conscription had been in effect for a considerable period of time.
And again, part of the problem was the corruption of civil officials who
for a certain price could buy a deferment, or the upper-class young men, they would naturally go off to school in France or wherever.
And conscription, again, was rather unfair.
And the conscription teams, I heard tales of press gangs going
along and around the streets of Saigon picking up young men and impressing them into the military.
I don't know if that's true or not.
I've just heard many, many stories about it.
How was the inter-service rivalry between American forces?
Do you believe that hampered our victory overall in the war?
Not at all.
I'm speaking from my own experience and there was no particular rivalry between Arvin and the U.S. Marine Corps in the period
1968 and 69, I was fortunate enough to share an area of operations with subordinate elements of the 1st Marine Division.
And with very few exceptions, the U.S. Army advisors got along just
great with the US Marines.
And because of this, there was a great deal of rapport between the US Army, that I was the representative of the US Army, and my subordinates and my superiors were the representatives of the US Army.
And as I recall, the senior American in the Corps was a Marine general.
I think his name was Cushman.
But his attitude called for cooperation between the Marines and the U.S. Army and the Vietnamese forces that were available in his Corps of Operations, Area of Operations, which coexisted with the
Now, late in that tour, there was an Army Corps also stationed in that area, and I believe a General Stilwell, he was a three-star general as I recall, was the deputy to the Marine General.
I'm not absolutely positive about the command structure.
But the Vietnamese Corps commander had his own personal Army advisor who was an Army colonel.
But the cooperation between the services and between the nationalities between the armies was good, always good.
As a matter of fact, my regiment
You see, I began as a battalion advisor, and after a few months I moved to the regiment and the deputy regimental advisor for the remainder of my tour.
But our artillery support was U.S. Marine artillery support.
Our aviation assets were either BNAF, Air Force, or Marine aviation as far as
When I say aviation, I'm talking primarily fixed-wing bombers, fighters, fighter-bombers.
The helicopter assets were U.S. Army assets, and we utilized those Army assets.
The Marine Corps utilized them.
And the made evacuation was either
Vietnam, that's Vietnamese Air Force helicopters.
Army helicopters are regular medevac choppers that we had access to.
And basically, as I recall, there were no significant priorities between Marine
If we needed artillery support, they gave it to us.
Sometimes if they were already firing a mission for the Marines, they might get it quicker.
They would continue to fire that mission, and then they might shift a battery to support us.
